ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great introduction to creative non-fiction. It allowed me to think more carefully about my writing, and to make it more engaging. It allows you to shed a new light to your past experiences, and how they can be molded in a unique and engaging essay.
learned a lot about writing narratives, which was something I had never really done before in college

The ability to craft compelling sentences, paragraphs, and essays, stronger reading comprehension skills, knowledge about literary devices and techniques, a deeper understanding of how to draft and edit essays, and, most importantly, a deeper understanding of both my peers and myself!
I learned how to be a better writer
learning more about creative writing.
SUCH A GREAT COURSE. Learned and improved in writing to much. Loved the feedback and engagement of the seminar style. First time taking a creative nonfiction writing course and I really enjoyed it
I learned how to write more clearly and efficiently while also learning different writing techniques.

I became a much better writer. The essays are flexible in topic, so you can basically write whatever you want however you want. That allowed for a lot of freedom in writing which I enjoyed. Because of this freedom, I learned how to be funnel creativity much more than I would if I took a class on academic writing.
I also learned about what a good essay is.
Experience with nonfiction writing and personal essay writing.
I believe I have learned many techniques to incorporate into my writing, and have gained valuable practice at writing nonfiction.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Interesting readings, careful feedback on writing, translating readings into methods that we can use in our own writing.
Points of improvement: perhaps less reading would allow for a more careful evaluation of the techniques that each author uses

readings were very fun and essays helped me learn a lot. I just wish there was more time available between receiving feedback from our first drafts and when the final draft is due so we can work on improving our essays more. Examples of good essays would also be helpful just to have an idea about what the expectations are

I adored 120! And I'm not an English or humanities-adjacent major! I thought that the seminar style format of the class worked so well, and the essays that we read and wrote during the semester were fun and interesting. Additionally, being able to turn in and receive feedback on an ungraded rough draft before being graded on a final piece relieved so much of my stress. Ms. Jones always facilitated productive discussions, and working with classmates on their essays helped us grow closer to one another. The classroom vibe was great :) 
Occasionally, the reading load was a bit heavy, as we often didn't have time to discuss every piece in class, but each essay chosen by Ms. Jones was both relevant and educational.
It was a brilliant course I loved it
It was a pretty solid course I dunno what could be improved.
Strengths are the seminar style and Ms Jones. Shes is very nice and gives great feedback on essays!
No weakness, the strengths were that the essays were spread out so it was a manageable workload.

Strengths: freedom to write how you want, fun/interesting readings, fun/interesting essay prompts, intimate and friendly classroom setup, not too demanding of a syllabus
weaknesses: the way we talked about the readings could be boring sometimes. This is because we would analyze their literary moves rather than just talking about what they wrote, which sort of beats the soul out of a writing piece through over analyzing and misses the point by not talking about it.

The topics for each essay are very interesting, and the readings that accompany them are sometimes very interesting. I think the readings are not always very strong, and oftentimes it felt like the essay we were reading could not really be applied to the essays we were expected to write due to a gap in experience, thematic nature, or simply length.

I enjoyed the peer review structure of the class, as I thought hearing from other students on my own piece was incredible helpful, while I also valued getting the chance to read and learn from my peers' work. I think the class is too focused on reading and analyzing writers' works; while it was incredibly helpful, I think we devoted too much time to talking about the pieces in class, and we could have benefited from doing more writing exercises in class. I also thought that while I got a lot of feedback in my papers, I often felt that I didn't completely understand why some of my papers would get one grade and others would get another. More clear feedback as to the reasoning behind the grading would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested by good writing and want yours to be better, take the class.
take this class if you are interested in narrative writing, as this will definitely force you out of your comfort zone if you haven't had much experience in it before

Yes! If you need a writing credit, and enjoy self reflection, 120 is the way to go. We had a mix of all grade levels in our section, and the fascinating blend of personalities and life experiences to learn from made this class the most personal academic experience I've had at yale so far. Be warned, though, that drafting and editing can take a large amount of time if you're a perfectionist about things like I am.
Yes it is an amazing course if you want to improve your writing.
yes I would. It was tough but a pretty nice experience to learn more about creative writing.
YES YES YES! My favorite course this year and it was such a nice break from traditionally academic research papers. The essays were all so fun for me to write
Yes, it is fun and allows you to write about yourself/experiences.
Yes because it is a good writing course that isn't a higher level one.

Yes. Great and fun way to improve writing. It's incredible to write for fun (which is what I would call doing the essays) and then have a experienced expert professor give you feedback and help you with your questions.

Not necessarily, the topics are interesting, but the overall course was not very engaging. If you are an english major, yes potentially, but for those not interesting in pursuing an english degree and simply wanting to explore the department, it seems like there are more fun, engaging courses offered.
Yes, I enjoyed this class and would recommend it to others.
